Posts.Content: Pleased to hear that you're op went well & you are recovering. I had my LD flap 9 weeks ago & know what you mean about the drains. I found them the worst part of the whole procedure. As for the food, I completely lost my appetite in hospital as the food was so revolting. I was in on Christmas day, so it was the first time in my life that I didn't have a Christmas dinner. Funnliy enough, we're having our family Christmas dinner this Sunday (better late than never). I don't know what your arm movement is like. I could barely lift my arm at first, but I can lift it right up now. Look forward to your update. Sally. X

Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Round 2-Triple Negative

Posts.Content: Hi everyone, I was diagnosed with DCIS three years ago and had a mastectomy and reconsruction. Three weeks ago I was diagnosed with invasive grade 3 cancer in the other breast. I had a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy last week. I've been back to the consultant today and have been told that the lymph nodes are clear, but it is triple negative breast cancer. I've got to have six months of chemo and then radiotherapy.  I've been researching TNBC and have filled myself with dread. Has anyone got anything positive to say about TNBC. I did look on the TNBC forum but it doesn't seem to be used much. I'm a very positive person, but I can feel the positivity draining away. Sally.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Round 2-Triple Negative

Posts.Content: Hi Kate, I had a mastectomy and reconstruction on 21st December 2011, so I'm 2 years down the line. I went into hospital on the 21st and came out on boxing day, so I spent Christmas day in hospital, which I admit I didn't cope very well with. I can honestly say that I had hardly any pain. I was a bit sore and had four drains in which were uncomfortable. Once the drains were removed (the 26th), I felt fine. I felt very tired for the first 2 weeks. I was given a list telling me when I could hoover, do house work, drive, etc. and I stuck to it, because I didn't want to end up in hospital. Over the next 3 weeks I gradually did more around the house and started to go further afield, walking or on  buses. I started driving after 6 weeks ( a struggle as I really missed driving, but was determined to do as I was told). My main problem was not being able to lift my arm. Exercise is paramount in getting movement back. Do the exercises that the physio gives you and ask for physio therapy. My physio therapist brought me back to life. Once I could fully lift my arm, I finally felt normal again. My advice is to take things slowly, don't over do it and exercise, exercise, exercise. You will come though this and will feel proud of yourself  for doing so. Everyone is different, but after 6 weeks (so you're looking at the end of January) I was back to normal and getting on with my life. I wish you all the best for the 20th and hope you have a restful Christmas. Sally. X
